Dear Hope James:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
October 3, 2023. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this
letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616) 204-
6992.

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CPA Rule 400.12212 Personnel records
(2) The personnel record must contain all the
following information before employment may occur:
(b) Verification of education.
One of twenty-four employee files reviewed did not contain verification of education
as required.
CPA Rule 400.12327 Special evaluation
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the
evaluation, an agency shall complete a written
report.
One of four special investigations reviewed did not have a report completed within
15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation.
CPA Rule 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy
(1) An agency’s medical and dental care policy must
include all the following:
2

(c) A physical examination for each child as follows,
unless a greater frequency is medically indicated:
(ii) A physical examination every 14 months.
One of eight foster care files reviewed did not have a periodic medical examination
within 14 months as required.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all
the following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(a) Child’s name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s
health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the
child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy
environment for the foster child and the foster
family, including information about siblings who do
not reside in the foster home as provided in federal
law.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
(j) Authorization to provide routine and emergency
medical care.
Four and eight foster care files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
information required within subsection a-j of this rule was provided to the caregivers
within the timeframes outlines within the rule.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8/26/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/20/2022
CPA Rule 400.12421 Visitation and family time; in person contact
3

information:

FOM 722-06B Family Team Meeting
FTM’s must occur within the required time frames as
outlined in the following tables:
Case Plan Development/Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30
calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption
At least three business days prior to a planned
change of placement or no later than three business
days after an unplanned placement change.
Planned and unplanned placement changes include
reunification, placement in a residential setting,
stepdown from a residential or hospital setting,
return from AWOLP, or request for change in foster
home/relative placements.
Two of eight foster care files reviewed did not have FTM’s completed as required.

F FOM 801-03 Medical passports
For children entering foster care, the initial medical
passport must be provided within two weeks of the
child's placement date to the following:
• Foster care provider.
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult re-entering foster care.
The actual date the medical passport is provided
must be documented in the electronic case
management record.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
• Participating legal parents, if the child is a
temporary court ward.
Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are
not
required after reunification.
• The child’s foster care provider:
At or prior to each placement.
• All medical and mental health professionals to
whom the child is newly referred to and accepted for
5

treatment and/or services prior to or at the first
scheduled appointment while the foster care case is
open, regardless of placement.
Subsequent medical passports are not required.
• • Older youth/young adults:
• Upon initial independent living placement (youth
age 16 and over).
• Upon exiting the foster care system (young adults
age 18 and older).
• Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC)
youth/young adult:
• Within two weeks of re-entry into voluntary foster
care.
• Upon exiting voluntary foster care.
Three of eight foster care files reviewed did not have medical passports and required
signatures.

8/26/2022 RENEWAL, CAP approved 9/20/2022
FOM 722-06H Quality visits
Quality visits between the caseworker and child have
been found to produce positive outcomes for children
in foster care. A quality visit is defined as one in which
the caseworker:
• Can meet with each child individually, without the
presence of other individuals, to give the child an
opportunity to ask questions as well as discuss the
current placement.
• Views the child's bedroom and sleeping
arrangements.
• Verifies safe sleep environments and practices for
infants under 12 months.
• Assesses each child’s educational, medical, dental,
mental health and other needs and takes appropriate
action or offers services in response to the identified
needs of each child.
6

• Shows interest in the child to build and establish
rapport.
• Shares and explains the case plan, including the plan
for parenting time, visits with siblings and other
relatives, and the child's permanency plan, in a
developmentally appropriate way while allowing the
child to ask questions and express viewpoints.
One of eight foster care files reviewed contained duplicate social work contacts for two
monthly home visits with youth in foster home as well as two contacts with caregiver.

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Applicable boxes for FTM’s must be checked.
• Separate home visit social work contacts and sibling visits social work contacts.
• Be sure to annotate PATP signature line if client refused to sign, emailed, mailed,
etc.
• Be sure to enter cancelled medical or dental appointments.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
7

• The facility did not request or require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF PERIOD UNDER REVIEW
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were 1 incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period. A special evaluation initiated on 11/1/2022 regarding allegations a licensed
relative caregiver was utilizing corporal punishment as discipline. The relative was
found to be in violation of licensing rules and agency policy. A CAP was
recommended, however the relative refused to sign. As a result, the agency has
sought revocation of the foster home license. The youth are no longer residing in
the home.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 2 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows. SIR
2023C0000226 was initiated on 2/8/2023 regarding allegations a staff member at
the independent living house was purchasing alcohol and vape pens for youth
placed in the home. The investigation determined a violation of rule 400.12206
staff qualifications. A CAP was approved on 4/12/2023 and continues to be
implemented.
The agency submitted an acceptable corrective action plan in response to the
renewal inspection completed on 8/26/2022 with a corrective action plan approved
on 9/20/2022. During the review the agency had fourteen violations. Four
violations were noted as repeat violations in the current inspection. During this
period under review the agency noted that overall compliance was impacted, in
part, by staff turnover.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The assessment reported the agency's difficulty in meeting requirements during
this review period. The agency has experienced high staff turnover. As a result,
the agency is constantly training new staff, and this also takes up a lot of time for
supervisors. In addition to staff turnover, the agency has experienced a high
number of placement crises over the past review period. This has added to the job
stress.
The Chief Administrator (CA) stated the previous year CAP yielded some
improvements. The agency made several changes to how HR files are managed
to ensure compliance. The agency has also implemented additional tracking for
special investigations and medical passports that have been successful. Internal
quarterly file audits are also being completed to assist with compliance. The CA
expressed confidence that several areas will improve over the next review period.
Financial Overview
8

Financial records were reviewed and there were no concerns identified.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Interviews were conducted with three staff via telephone. Staff reported feeling
supported by supervision as well as coworkers. Staff also reported the transition to
a new Chief Administrator has gone well. There were no concerns reported.
Description of Agency Walk Through
The agency maintains sufficient office space, equipment and supplies to ensure
delivery of foster care, licensing and independent living services. All files were
stored securely.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
The DCWL Agency Analyst identified two safety concern as follows:
Safety Alert #1: Unlicensed relative caregiver was in need of batteries for a smoke
detector.
Resolution: Agency purchased a new smoke detector on 6/23/2023. The licensing
team lead activated and installed the smoke detector in the home. A picture of the
smoke detector was provided as verification.
Safety Alert 2: Unlicensed relative caregiver's adult daughter and her two children
moved into the home but are not listed as household members in the provider
record.
Resolution: An updated Relative Safety Screen (DHS 5570) was completed to add
relative caregiver's adult daughter and her two children to the provider record.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
